Vitamin A.Description: Vitamin A is a fat-soluble vitamin that plays a critical role in vision, immune function, and cellular communication in the body. It exists in two forms, retinol and beta-carotene, with the former found in animal products and the latter in plant-based foods. While vitamin A is essential for overall health, excessive intake can lead to toxicity, causing symptoms such as nausea, dizziness, and blurred vision.

Boron.Description: Boron is a trace mineral that is essential for human health, but required in very small amounts. It plays a crucial role in maintaining bone health, as well as aiding in the absorption of calcium, magnesium, and vitamin D. While boron deficiency is rare, individuals who consume a low fruit and vegetable diet may not be meeting their daily boron requirements, which can lead to negative impacts on bone health.

Vitamin B1.Description: Vitamin B1, also known as thiamin, is a water-soluble vitamin that is essential for the metabolism of carbohydrates, proteins, and fats. It plays a crucial role in energy production, as it is required to convert glucose into energy that the body can use. Thiamin deficiency can lead to a condition called beriberi, which causes symptoms such as weakness, loss of appetite, and nerve damage.

Vitamin B2.Description: Vitamin B2, also known as riboflavin, is a water-soluble vitamin that plays a critical role in energy metabolism and the maintenance of healthy skin, eyes, and nervous system. It is essential for the production of flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) and flavin mononucleotide (FMN), two coenzymes that are involved in numerous enzymatic reactions in the body. Riboflavin deficiency can lead to a condition called ariboflavinosis, which causes symptoms such as sore throat, skin rash, and inflammation of the tongue.

Vitamin B3.Description: Vitamin B3, also known as niacin, is a water-soluble vitamin that plays a crucial role in energy metabolism and the maintenance of healthy skin, nerves, and digestion. It is required for the synthesis of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD) and nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADP), coenzymes that are involved in many cellular processes, including the conversion of food into energy. Niacin deficiency can lead to a condition called pellagra, which causes symptoms such as skin rash, diarrhea, and dementia.

Vitamin B5.Description: Vitamin B5, also known as pantothenic acid, is a water-soluble vitamin that is required for the metabolism of carbohydrates, proteins, and fats. It is an essential component of coenzyme A (CoA) and acyl carrier protein (ACP), which are involved in numerous enzymatic reactions in the body, including the production of energy. Pantothenic acid deficiency is rare, but can lead to symptoms such as fatigue, insomnia, and numbness and tingling in the hands and feet.

Vitamin B6.Description: Vitamin B6, also known as pyridoxine, is a water-soluble vitamin that plays a crucial role in amino acid metabolism, the synthesis of neurotransmitters, and the formation of red blood cells. It is required for the conversion of tryptophan to serotonin and niacin and also for the production of the hormones serotonin, norepinephrine, and melatonin. Pyridoxine deficiency can lead to a range of symptoms, including anemia, dermatitis, and neurological disorders.

Vitamin B7.Description: Vitamin B7, also known as biotin, is a water-soluble vitamin that plays a critical role in the metabolism of carbohydrates, proteins, and fats. It is necessary for the production of glucose and fatty acids and is involved in the synthesis of amino acids and nucleic acids. Biotin deficiency is rare, but can lead to symptoms such as skin rash, hair loss, and neurological problems.

Vitamin B9.Description: Vitamin B9, also known as folate or folic acid, is a water-soluble vitamin that is essential for DNA synthesis and cell division. It is required for the production of red and white blood cells, as well as the conversion of homocysteine to methionine. Folate deficiency can lead to a range of symptoms, including anemia, birth defects, and an increased risk of certain cancers.

Vitamin B12.Description: Vitamin B12, also known as cobalamin, is a water-soluble vitamin that plays a crucial role in the synthesis of DNA and red blood cells. It is required for the proper functioning of the nervous system and the metabolism of amino acids and fatty acids. Cobalamin deficiency can lead to symptoms such as fatigue, weakness, and neurological problems, and is most commonly seen in strict vegetarians and individuals with certain medical conditions that affect absorption of the vitamin.

Calcium.Description: Calcium is an essential mineral required for the growth and maintenance of strong bones and teeth. It also plays a critical role in muscle function, nerve transmission, and blood clotting. While dairy products are a rich source of calcium, other sources include leafy green vegetables, nuts, and fortified foods.

Choline.Description: Choline is an essential nutrient that plays a critical role in several processes in the body, including brain development, nerve function, and metabolism. It is necessary for the production of acetylcholine, a neurotransmitter involved in learning and memory. While choline can be synthesized by the body to some extent, dietary sources such as eggs, meat, and fish are the most significant sources of choline.

Copper.Description: Copper is an essential mineral required for the production of red blood cells and the maintenance of healthy connective tissues, such as bones, skin, and cartilage. It is also involved in the production of energy and the function of the nervous system. While copper deficiency is rare, individuals who consume a diet that is low in copper or high in zinc may be at risk of deficiency.

Vitamin C.Description: Vitamin C, also known as ascorbic acid, is a water-soluble vitamin that plays a crucial role in several physiological processes, including the synthesis of collagen, the absorption of iron, and the function of the immune system. It also functions as an antioxidant, protecting cells from damage caused by harmful molecules called free radicals. While citrus fruits are the most well-known source of vitamin C, it is also found in many other fruits and vegetables, such as strawberries, kiwi, broccoli, and bell peppers.

Vitamin E.Description: Vitamin E is a fat-soluble vitamin that acts as an antioxidant, protecting cells from damage caused by free radicals. It also plays a role in immune function, DNA repair, and other important physiological processes. Nuts, seeds, vegetable oils, and leafy green vegetables are all good sources of vitamin E, and most people can meet their daily requirements through a balanced diet.

Vitamin D.Description: Vitamin D is a fat-soluble vitamin that is important for bone health, as it aids in the absorption of calcium and phosphorus. It is also involved in the regulation of the immune system, insulin secretion, and cell growth and differentiation. While the body can produce vitamin D when the skin is exposed to sunlight, dietary sources such as fatty fish, egg yolks, and fortified foods may also contribute to vitamin D intake.

Iodine.Description: Iodine is an essential mineral that plays a critical role in thyroid function, which regulates metabolism and growth. It is necessary for the production of thyroid hormones, which are involved in several physiological processes, including brain development, bone maintenance, and body temperature regulation. While iodine is present in some foods, such as seaweed, dairy products, and fish, iodized salt is the most common dietary source of iodine.

Iron.Description: Iron is a mineral that is essential for the formation of hemoglobin, a protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen throughout the body. It is also involved in several physiological processes, including immune function, energy production, and cognitive development. While meat, poultry, and fish are good sources of iron, plant-based sources such as beans, lentils, and spinach are also important dietary sources for vegetarians and vegans.

Vitamin K.Description: Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin that is important for blood clotting and bone health. It is necessary for the synthesis of several proteins involved in blood coagulation and bone metabolism. While leafy green vegetables, such as spinach and kale, are the best dietary sources of vitamin K, it is also found in other foods, including some vegetable oils, dairy products, and meats.

Magnesium.Description: Magnesium is a mineral that is important for a wide range of physiological functions, including muscle and nerve function, energy production, and bone health. It also plays a role in the regulation of blood pressure and blood sugar levels. While nuts, seeds, legumes, and leafy green vegetables are good sources of magnesium, many people do not consume enough of this mineral through their diet and may benefit from supplementation.

Manganese.Description: Manganese is a trace mineral that plays a role in several physiological processes, including bone development, wound healing, and the metabolism of carbohydrates, amino acids, and cholesterol. It also functions as an antioxidant, protecting cells from damage caused by free radicals. While whole grains, nuts, and leafy green vegetables are good sources of manganese, most people can meet their daily requirements through a balanced diet.

Molybdenum.Description: Molybdenum is a trace mineral that plays a role in several physiological processes, including the metabolism of sulfur-containing amino acids and the detoxification of harmful substances in the liver. It also helps to activate enzymes that are involved in the breakdown of certain drugs and toxins. While legumes, nuts, and leafy green vegetables are good dietary sources of molybdenum, deficiency is rare as the body requires only small amounts of this mineral.

Phosphorus.Description: Phosphorus is an essential mineral that plays a vital role in the formation and maintenance of healthy bones and teeth. It is also involved in several physiological processes, including energy production and DNA synthesis. While phosphorus is found in many foods, including dairy products, meat, and fish, it is also present in smaller amounts in plant-based foods such as whole grains and nuts.

Potassium.Description: Potassium is a mineral that is essential for numerous bodily functions, including muscle and nerve function, fluid balance, and blood pressure regulation. Adequate potassium intake has been associated with a reduced risk of stroke, heart disease, and kidney stones. Good dietary sources of potassium include fruits and vegetables, such as bananas, potatoes, and spinach.

Selenium.Description: Selenium is a trace mineral that is essential for several bodily functions, including thyroid hormone metabolism and antioxidant defense. It is found in a variety of foods, including seafood, meat, and grains, but the amount can vary depending on the selenium content of the soil where the food was grown or raised. Adequate selenium intake has been associated with a reduced risk of certain chronic diseases, such as heart disease and some types of cancer.

Zinc.Description: Zinc is an essential mineral that is involved in numerous bodily functions, including immune function, protein synthesis, and wound healing. It is also important for taste perception, and adequate zinc intake has been associated with a reduced risk of age-related macular degeneration. Good dietary sources of zinc include oysters, beef, pork, and legumes.
